message.content:
<<<api>>>: Map.get
<<<code>>>: 
To sort the array by day, you can use the Collections.sort method and provide a custom Comparator that compares the days. Here's an example:

public void sortArray() {
    // Assuming your array is called "array"
    Collections.sort(array, new Comparator<String>() {
        @Override
        public int compare(String day1, String day2) {
            // Convert the days to integers for comparison
            int day1Index = getDayIndex(day1);
            int day2Index = getDayIndex(day2);
            
            // Compare the integers
            return Integer.compare(day1Index, day2Index);
        }
        
        private int getDayIndex(String day) {
            // Map the days to their corresponding indices
            Map<String, Integer> dayIndices = new HashMap<>();
            dayIndices.put("Monday", 1);
            dayIndices.put("Tuesday", 2);
            dayIndices.put("Wednesday", 3);
            dayIndices.put("Thursday", 4);
            dayIndices.put("Friday", 5);
            
            // Get the index for the given day
            Integer index = dayIndices.get(day);
            
            // If the day is not found, assign a high index so it appears at the end
            if (index == null) {
                index = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
            }
            
            return index;
        }
    });
}

<<<explanation>>>: 
In the sortArray method, we use the Collections.sort method to sort the array. We provide a custom Comparator that compares the days. The compare method converts the days to integers using a helper method getDayIndex. The getDayIndex method maps the days to their corresponding indices using a Map. If a day is not found in the map, we assign a high index (Integer.MAX_VALUE) so that it appears at the end of the sorted array.
